Center”

• Conduct periodic assessments of Ames workforce’s:
• Conduct periodic assessments of Ames workforce’s:

Survey Findings
Survey Findings

• Ames’ Strengths
• Ames’ Strengths

• Areas of Concern
• Areas of Concern

• Follow-Up Actions
• Follow-Up Actions

Understanding of Workplace Diversity
Understanding of Workplace Diversity

– Most respondents understand the NASA Ames Diversity message – 75 percent agree that diversity is not just about physical characteristics
– Most respondents understand the NASA Ames Diversity message
– 75 percent agree that diversity is not just about physical characteristics

– Some respondents define workplace diversity somewhat narrowly in terms
– Some respondents define workplace diversity somewhat narrowly in terms

of equal opportunity, affirmative action, and quotas
of equal opportunity, affirmative action, and quotas

Ames’ Strengths
Ames’ Strengths

Areas of Concern
Areas of Concern

Possible Actions
Possible Actions

– Promote better understanding of the broad meaning of workplace diversity – Consider using the widely read Astrogram as a promotion tool
– Promote better understanding of the broad meaning of workplace diversity
– Consider using the widely read Astrogram as a promotion tool – C o n s i d e r
u s i n g
t h e
w i d e l y
r e a d

a
p r o m o t i o n
t o o l

Benefits of Workplace Diversity
Benefits of Workplace Diversity

Ames’ Strengths
Ames’ Strengths

Areas of Concern
Areas of Concern

Possible Actions
Possible Actions

– More than 80% of Ames respondents believe that diversity can be a source
– More than 80% of Ames respondents believe that diversity can be a source

of business advantage, and many cited its importance to the Center’s mission
of business advantage, and many cited its importance to the Center’s
mission

– A minority do not see a link between a diverse workplace and better
– A minority do not see a link between a diverse workplace and better

products, increased workforce productivity, and creativity and innovation
products, increased workforce productivity, and creativity and innovation

– Provide more concrete examples of the relationship between workplace
– Provide more concrete examples of the relationship between workplace

diversity and workplace benefits in diversity training classes and promotional activities
diversity and workplace benefits in diversity training classes and
promotional activities

– Consider offering Myers-Briggs training to managers and supervisors
– Consider offering Myers-Briggs training to managers and supervisors

Organizational Culture: General Perceptions
Organizational Culture: General Perceptions

Ames’ Strengths
Ames’ Strengths

– Overall, respondents have positive general perceptions about the organizational culture:
– Overall, respondents have positive general perceptions about the organizational culture:

About 80% believe Ames policies promote fair treatment of employees, and 84% agree that employees have a responsibility to encourage diversity
About 80% believe Ames policies promote fair treatment of employees, and 84% agree that
employees have a responsibility to encourage diversity

– Only 29% of respondents disagree with the statement that workplace diversity sometimes
– Only 29% of respondents disagree with the statement that workplace diversity sometimes

– Only two thirds of employees believe their coworkers actually encourage and promote
– Only two thirds of employees believe their coworkers actually encourage and promote

Areas of Concern
Areas of Concern

leads to workplace problems
leads to workplace problems

workforce inclusion
workforce inclusion

Possible Actions
Possible Actions

– Address the first area of concern by:
– Address the first area of concern by:

• Exploring the topic in employee focus groups. To reduce reticence in sharing honest
• Exploring the topic in employee focus groups. To reduce reticence in sharing honest

feelings, keep the groups homogeneous in terms of gender (e.g., females in one group and males in another), supervisory status, and race/ethnicity Incorporating this topic into diversity training courses
feelings, keep the groups homogeneous in terms of gender (e.g., females in one group
and males in another), supervisory status, and race/ethnicity
Incorporating this topic into diversity training courses

– Guide all employees in practical ways to implement diversity principles in their work units and
– Guide all employees in practical ways to implement diversity principles in their work units and

teams
teams

Diversity Training
Diversity Training

– Less than 10% of respondents have a negative opinion about Ames’ efforts to encourage
– Less than 10% of respondents have a negative opinion about Ames’ efforts to encourage

employees to participate in diversity training
employees to participate in diversity training

– About 50% of respondents indicated a need to improve diversity training at Ames, citing:
– About 50% of respondents indicated a need to improve diversity training at Ames, citing:

• Too much focus on physical differences • Passive “lecturing” on compliance with equal opportunity (EEO) laws and agency
• Too much focus on physical differences
• Passive “lecturing” on compliance with equal opportunity (EEO) laws and agency

Ames’ Strengths
Ames’ Strengths

Area of Concern
Area of Concern

policies
policies

Possible Actions
Possible Actions

– Develop training that is more interactive – Align content with the agency’s diversity mission statement and principles – Differentiate diversity mission from EEO compliance – Consider conducting a focus group or interviews with former trainees to gather their ideas
– Develop training that is more interactive
– Align content with the agency’s diversity mission statement and principles
– Differentiate diversity mission from EEO compliance
– Consider conducting a focus group or interviews with former trainees to gather their ideas

for improving the training
for improving the training

– Monitor training effectiveness; revise training in response to participants’ evaluations and
– Monitor training effectiveness; revise training in response to participants’ evaluations and

progress in meeting identified training goals
progress in meeting identified training goals

– Be realistic about the purpose and goals of diversity training. The diversity literature
– Be realistic about the purpose and goals of diversity training. The diversity literature

indicates that diversity training, in and of itself, is insufficient as the primary mechanism for achieving a diverse workforce
indicates that diversity training, in and of itself, is insufficient as the primary mechanism for
achieving a diverse workforce

Manager and Supervisors
Manager and Supervisors

– 60% to 70% of respondents believe that managers and supervisors value employees of
– 60% to 70% of respondents believe that managers and supervisors value employees of

diverse backgrounds and viewpoints and encourage them to share their opinions
diverse backgrounds and viewpoints and encourage them to share their opinions

– However, respondents generally give managers and supervisors higher marks for what they say than for what they actually do to ensure effective workplace diversity, with the perceived difference between words and action being in the 10% to 20% range
– However, respondents generally give managers and supervisors higher marks for what
they say than for what they actually do to ensure effective workplace diversity, with the
perceived difference between words and action being in the 10% to 20% range

Ames’ Strengths
Ames’ Strengths

Area of Concern
Area of Concern

Possible Actions
Possible Actions

– Review existing responsibilities of managers and supervisors for promoting and
– Review existing responsibilities of managers and supervisors for promoting and

implementing diversity principles
implementing diversity principles

– If necessary, clarify the responsibilities so that they can be measured and monitored – Communicate and discuss the goals with managers and supervisors. Share best
– If necessary, clarify the responsibilities so that they can be measured and monitored
– Communicate and discuss the goals with managers and supervisors. Share best

practices with them for achieving the goals. Provide them with the support they need to perform effectively
practices with them for achieving the goals. Provide them with the support they need to
perform effectively

– Incorporate the goals into their performance appraisals and hold them accountable for
– Incorporate the goals into their performance appraisals and hold them accountable for

– Recognize and reward managers and supervisors for outstanding achievements in
– Recognize and reward managers and supervisors for outstanding achievements in

progress in meeting them
progress in meeting them

improving workplace diversity
improving workplace diversity

Personal Perceptions: Fair Treatment and Possible Reprisals
Personal Perceptions: Fair Treatment and
Possible Reprisals

– Very low percentages of respondents (from 1% to 5%) indicated they are treated unfairly
– Very low percentages of respondents (from 1% to 5%) indicated they are treated unfairly

because of assumptions about their personal characteristics
because of assumptions about their personal characteristics

Ames’ Strengths
Ames’ Strengths

Areas of Concern
Areas of Concern

– Non-Whites and women are less positive about experiencing unfair treatment – Only 57% of respondents disagree with the statement that there will be negative
– Non-Whites and women are less positive about experiencing unfair treatment
– Only 57% of respondents disagree with the statement that there will be negative

consequences for them if they report unfair treatment at work, with notable differences between Whites and Non-Whites, men and women, supervisors and non-supervisors, and younger and older employees
consequences for them if they report unfair treatment at work, with notable differences
between Whites and Non-Whites, men and women, supervisors and non-supervisors, and
younger and older employees

Possible Actions
Possible Actions

for discussion
for discussion

– If focus groups or interviews are held with various employee subgroups, include these topics
– If focus groups or interviews are held with various employee subgroups, include these topics

– In all training for managers and supervisors, discuss employee perceptions about possible
– In all training for managers and supervisors, discuss employee perceptions about possible

reprisals for reports of unfair treatment
reprisals for reports of unfair treatment

– Assure employees that Ames will not tolerate reprisals for any reports of unfair treatment
– Assure employees that Ames will not tolerate reprisals for any reports of unfair treatment

Opportunities for Advancement
Opportunities for Advancement

– Approximately 70% of respondents believe that Ames gives them adequate
– Approximately 70% of respondents believe that Ames gives them adequate

opportunities to use their skills and advance in their careers
opportunities to use their skills and advance in their careers

Ames’ Strengths
Ames’ Strengths

Area of Concern
Area of Concern

– Many respondents would like more mentoring and more opportunities for
– Many respondents would like more mentoring and more opportunities for

professional development
professional development

– Many respondents think assumptions made about them by supervisors and
– Many respondents think assumptions made about them by supervisors and

coworkers limit their opportunities for professional development
coworkers limit their opportunities for professional development

– Perceptions about these topics are notably less positive among women, Non- Whites, non-supervisors, respondents 40 years and over, and respondents working at NASA Ames for more than 10 years
– Perceptions about these topics are notably less positive among women, Non-
Whites, non-supervisors, respondents 40 years and over, and respondents
working at NASA Ames for more than 10 years

Opportunities for Advancement (continued)
Opportunities for Advancement (continued)

Possible Actions
Possible Actions

– Have agency leaders review both their formal and informal procedures for
– Have agency leaders review both their formal and informal procedures for

identifying employees with supervisory and managerial potential. Make sure no one is inadvertently overlooked - broaden the pool beyond “the usual suspects.” Inform all employees of professional growth opportunities and job openings for supervisors and managers
identifying employees with supervisory and managerial potential. Make sure no one
is inadvertently overlooked - broaden the pool beyond “the usual suspects.” Inform
all employees of professional growth opportunities and job openings for supervisors
and managers

– Consider using formal and informal mentoring programs to promote diversity in the
– Consider using formal and informal mentoring programs to promote diversity in the

upper ranks
upper ranks

– Adopt industry best practice - Set specific diversity goals and treat each like any
– Adopt industry best practice - Set specific diversity goals and treat each like any

other major organizational goal. That is, senior leaders champion the goal and:
other major organizational goal. That is, senior leaders champion the goal and:

• Assign responsibility to an individual or group for achieving the goal • Provide the necessary resources to accomplish the goal • Establish a reasonable timeline • Hold the responsible person or group members accountable for their
• Assign responsibility to an individual or group for achieving the goal
• Provide the necessary resources to accomplish the goal
• Establish a reasonable timeline
• Hold the responsible person or group members accountable for their

performance
performance

and Initiatives

Ames’ Strengths

Areas of Concern

– The survey findings indicate low awareness of various diversity initiatives and

information sources, particularly the:

Ames’ Effectiveness in Creating an Inclusive Work Environment
Ames’ Effectiveness in Creating an Inclusive
Work Environment

– About 70% of respondents have positive perceptions about Ames’ overall effectiveness in promoting professional growth, fostering mutual trust and respect, and valuing individual contributions
– About 70% of respondents have positive perceptions about Ames’ overall effectiveness in
promoting professional growth, fostering mutual trust and respect, and valuing individual
contributions

Areas of Concern

– Positive perceptions are somewhat less common about Ames’ overall effectiveness in
– Positive perceptions are somewhat less common about Ames’ overall effectiveness in

creating a supportive environment for all employees and creating a strong teamwork culture
creating a supportive environment for all employees and creating a strong teamwork culture

– Again, for some of the overall effectiveness items, positive perceptions are less common
– Again, for some of the overall effectiveness items, positive perceptions are less common

among Non-Whites, women, non-supervisors, respondents working at Ames for more than 10 years, and those 40 years old and over
among Non-Whites, women, non-supervisors, respondents working at Ames for more than

subgroups

– Meet with employees individually, other than during performance appraisals, to discuss the

support needed to achieve their potential at NASA Ames
support needed to achieve their potential at NASA Ames

Research Question 2:
Findings Part 1: General Perceptions about the Organizational
Culture

Some Strong Positive Findings, But They Come With Qualifications
Some Strong Positive Findings, But They Come With Qualifications

About 80% of respondents agreed that NASA Ames promotes fair treatment of all employees, although only 72.6% of Non-White respondents agreed.
About 80% of respondents agreed that NASA Ames promotes fair treatment
of all employees, although only 72.6% of Non-White respondents agreed.

83.7% agreed that all employees have a responsibility to promote workplace diversity, but only about 65% said employees actually encourage workplace participation by coworkers with different characteristics or viewpoints.
83.7% agreed that all employees have a responsibility to promote workplace
diversity, but only about 65% said employees actually encourage workplace
participation by coworkers with different characteristics or viewpoints.

81.2% of respondents said diversity training is encouraged, but only about 50% agreed that the training is useful.
81.2% of respondents said diversity training is encouraged, but only about
50% agreed that the training is useful.

Challenges
Challenges

• Only 35.3% of respondents report NASA Ames uses diversity effectively to
• Only 35.3% of respondents report NASA Ames uses diversity effectively to

increase workforce productivity and only about 30% disagreed that workplace diversity sometimes leads to workplace problems.
increase workforce productivity and only about 30% disagreed that
workplace diversity sometimes leads to workplace problems.
